choices.text: Post traumatic dystrophy with Complex regional pain syndrome

questions.text: A woman presents with pain, swelling and redness of knee joint and hand. There were associated complaints of Morning stiffness with problem in squatting. The swelling spared the DIP joints. The image of the patient’s hands is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) Rheumatoid Arthritis is a chronic inflammatory autoimmune disease that primarily affects the small joints symmetrically. The clinical picture in this case — pain and swelling in the knee and hand joints, morning stiffness, difficulty in squatting, and sparing of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints — is classic for RA. The image shows ulnar deviation and swan-neck deformities, which are hallmark features of advanced RA. These deformities occur due to long-term synovial inflammation leading to joint damage and tendon displacement. Incorrect options: B. Osteoarthritis OA typically affects the DIP joints (e.g., Heberden's nodes) and is associated with bony swelling and less prominent morning stiffness (usually <30 minutes). It is more wear-and-tear related, and not symmetric in distribution. Hence, less likely here. C. Villonodular Synovitis (PVNS) PVNS is a rare condition causing localized or diffuse synovial hypertrophy, often involving a single joint (commonly the knee). It does not present with symmetric hand joint involvement or classic systemic RA features. D. Post-traumatic Dystrophy (CRPS) CRPS typically follows trauma and is marked by disproportionate pain, swelling, and autonomic changes (e.g., sweating, color change), rather than symmetric joint involvement or classic hand deformities as seen here.

questions.text: Which of the following cannot be diagnosed if ANA is negative?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) SLE Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) almost always presents with a positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) test. ANA is highly sensitive (around 95-98%) for SLE, meaning a negative ANA essentially rules out SLE in most cases. Because ANA is positive in nearly all patients with active SLE, it is considered a key screening test for diagnosis. Incorrect Options: A) Scleroderma While ANA is positive in the majority of scleroderma patients (about 90%), a small percentage can have negative ANA, so diagnosis is still possible with clinical features and other specific autoantibodies. C) Sjogren Syndrome ANA is positive in many patients with Sjogren’s syndrome, but it is not universally positive. Diagnosis can also be made by clinical features, other autoantibodies (anti-Ro, anti-La), and salivary gland biopsy even if ANA is negative. D) Discoid Lupus Erythematosus (DLE) DLE is a form of cutaneous lupus that may have negative ANA in many patients, since it is a localized skin disease. Diagnosis often depends on skin biopsy and clinical examination, so ANA negativity does not rule out DLE.

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A-5, B-3, C-2, and D-1 The correct response is A-5, B-3, C-2, D-1, as each antibody is specifically associated with a characteristic autoimmune disorder. Anti Jo-1 is an antibody directed against histidyl tRNA synthetase and is classically seen in polymyositis and dermatomyositis, especially in patients with antisynthetase syndrome, which includes interstitial lung disease, arthritis, and mechanic’s hands. Anti-topoisomerase I (Scl-70) is specific for systemic sclerosis, especially the diffuse cutaneous form, and indicates a higher risk for pulmonary fibrosis. Anti-U1 RNP is most strongly associated with Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD), a condition with overlapping features of lupus, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis. Anti-Smith is a highly specific marker for SLE (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus), though not sensitive. Its presence strongly supports an SLE diagnosis when found. Incorrect Options: Option B: A-4, B-2, C-5, D-3 Anti Jo-1 is not primarily associated with synthetase syndrome alone in this matching format (the correct pair was dermatomyositis). Anti-topoisomerase is wrongly paired with CDT instead of systemic sclerosis. Anti-U1 RNP does not match with dermatomyositis but with MCTD. Anti-Smith is incorrectly linked with systemic sclerosis, not SLE. Option C: A-3, B-4, C-1, D-2 This option misplaces several antibodies: Anti Jo-1 is not related to systemic sclerosis. Anti-topoisomerase and anti-Smith are also mismatched. Anti-U1 RNP is wrongly assigned to SLE, whereas it's a marker for MCTD. Option D: A-1, B-2, C-3, D-4 Again, all pairings are incorrect in this option: Anti Jo-1 is not associated with SLE. Anti-topoisomerase and U1 RNP are both mismatched. Anti-Smith is wrongfully matched with antisynthetase syndrome.

questions.text: What is the best nutritional regimen end stage CKD patients:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) High calorie, low volume In patients with end-stage CKD, especially those on dialysis, maintaining adequate caloric intake is critical due to increased catabolism and nutritional losses during dialysis. However, fluid overload is a common issue because the kidneys can no longer effectively excrete excess fluid. Therefore, the nutritional strategy should be to provide high-calorie nutrition in a low-volume format to meet energy needs without causing fluid overload. This approach helps prevent malnutrition and maintains energy balance while keeping fluid intake within safe limits. Incorrect Options: A) Low calorie, low volume This regimen does not meet the energy requirements of end-stage CKD patients, risking protein-energy malnutrition—a common and serious complication in these patients. B) Low calorie, high volume This approach also fails to meet caloric needs and increases the risk of fluid overload, which can lead to pulmonary edema, hypertension, and congestive heart failure in CKD patients. D) High calorie, high volume While this meets energy requirements, it introduces excessive fluid that cannot be excreted effectively, leading to dangerous fluid overload. This regimen is contraindicated in end-stage CKD.

questions.text: Themes & Focus: Arthritis Options list Lead in questions: For each description below, choose the single most likely diagnoses from the below list of options 2. A 32-years-old lady with joint pain, oral ulcers and skin rashes that worsen when she moves out of her home.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) SLE Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) is a chronic autoimmune disease that commonly affects young women and presents with a constellation of symptoms, including arthralgia (joint pain), oral ulcers, and photosensitive skin rashes—especially malar (butterfly-shaped) rash. The key feature in this case is that the rash worsens with sun exposure, which is characteristic of the photosensitivity seen in SLE. The combination of joint involvement, mucocutaneous symptoms, and photosensitivity strongly suggests SLE. Incorrect Options: A) Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) RA typically presents with symmetric joint pain and stiffness, especially in the small joints of the hands and feet. It does not commonly involve oral ulcers or photosensitive rashes, which makes RA unlikely in this case. C) Pseudogout Pseudogout usually affects older individuals and presents with acute monoarthritis (often in the knee), due to calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition. It does not involve oral ulcers or skin rashes, and is not linked to photosensitivity. D) Gout Gout is more common in middle-aged to older men, and presents as acute monoarthritis, classically affecting the first metatarsophalangeal joint (big toe). It is not associated with oral ulcers or photosensitive rashes.

questions.text: Themes & Focus: Arthritis Options list Lead in questions: For each description below, choose the single most likely diagnoses from the below list of options 3. A 46-years-old man with history of 10 years low back pain. On radiology B/L ?xed sacroiliac joints and syndesmophytes in the lumbar spine.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS) The description is classic for Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS)—a seronegative spondyloarthropathy primarily affecting the axial skeleton. It commonly presents in young men with chronic inflammatory low back pain (often beginning before age 40), morning stiffness, and improves with exercise. Radiologic hallmarks include: Bilateral sacroiliitis (fusion or sclerosis of sacroiliac joints) Syndesmophytes (bony growths within ligaments of the spine leading to a “bamboo spine” appearance) AS is associated with HLA-B27 positivity and does not typically involve peripheral joints or systemic features like oral ulcers (as seen in SLE or RA). Incorrect Options: A) Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) RA usually affects peripheral joints (small joints of hands and feet) in a symmetric fashion. Axial involvement is rare, and sacroiliac joint fusion is not characteristic. B) Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) SLE can cause arthritis, but it's usually non-erosive, migratory, and does not lead to spinal fusion or sacroiliitis. Also, SLE is more common in younger women, not middle-aged men. C) Pseudogout Pseudogout affects larger peripheral joints (like the knee) in older adults. It presents with acute joint pain, not chronic back pain or spinal changes like syndesmophytes. D) Gout Gout usually presents with acute monoarthritis, often of the first metatarsophalangeal joint (big toe). It does not involve the spine or sacroiliac joints.

questions.text: Uremic Symptom not improved after dialysis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Peripheral neuropathy Peripheral neuropathy is a common long-term complication of chronic kidney disease (CKD), especially in uremia. It typically presents as a distal, symmetric sensorimotor polyneuropathy. Unlike many uremic symptoms, peripheral neuropathy does not significantly improve with dialysis. This is because the nerve damage is often due to chronic exposure to uremic toxins and metabolic disturbances that have already caused structural changes to nerves. Therefore, even after dialysis starts and uremic toxin levels are reduced, the neurological damage may persist. Incorrect Options: B) Seizure Uremic seizures are caused by accumulation of toxins, electrolyte imbalances (e.g., hyponatremia), or metabolic derangements. Dialysis effectively clears toxins and corrects imbalances, typically resolving or improving seizures. C) Pericarditis Uremic pericarditis occurs due to irritation of the pericardium by retained uremic toxins. Dialysis usually leads to resolution of pericardial symptoms if initiated promptly, especially in acute cases. D) Metabolic alkalosis This is not typically a uremic symptom, and patients with kidney failure more commonly present with metabolic acidosis due to decreased acid excretion. In any case, acid-base disturbances (including alkalosis, if present) generally improve with dialysis, as it corrects the underlying metabolic imbalance.

questions.text: CKD With Gfr<30ml/min. Which Diuretic Can Be Used?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Metolazone In patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) and a glomerular filtration rate (GFR) below 30 ml/min, diuretic efficacy becomes significantly reduced, particularly for thiazide diuretics, due to their site of action in the distal convoluted tubule, which receives less sodium as kidney function declines. Metolazone, although structurally similar to thiazides, is a thiazide-like diuretic that remains effective even at low GFRs, including levels <30 ml/min. It works by inhibiting sodium reabsorption in the distal tubule and has an enhanced ability to augment diuresis when combined with loop diuretics like furosemide, making it especially useful in volume overload conditions in advanced CKD. Its unique efficacy at low GFRs distinguishes it from other thiazide and thiazide-like diuretics. Incorrect Options: A) Hydrochlorothiazide Hydrochlorothiazide is a standard thiazide diuretic that loses effectiveness when GFR falls below 30 ml/min. It is not recommended for use in patients with advanced CKD due to poor diuretic response in this population. B) Chlorthalidone Although chlorthalidone is a long-acting thiazide-like diuretic with some evidence suggesting slightly better efficacy than hydrochlorothiazide, it still becomes ineffective when GFR drops below 30 ml/min. Hence, it is not ideal in advanced CKD. D) Indapamide Indapamide is another thiazide-like diuretic with antihypertensive properties, but similar to chlorthalidone and hydrochlorothiazide, its efficacy diminishes significantly when GFR is <30 ml/min. Therefore, it is not the preferred choice in such cases.

questions.text: All are used as first line treatment in rheumatoid arthritis except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Azathioprine Azathioprine is not used as a first-line treatment in rheumatoid arthritis (RA). It is an immunosuppressive agent primarily indicated in refractory cases or when patients are intolerant or unresponsive to first-line DMARDs. Although azathioprine has immunomodulatory effects, its use is limited due to a higher risk of toxicity, including myelosuppression, hepatotoxicity, and increased susceptibility to infections. It is typically reserved for specific clinical scenarios, such as coexisting systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or organ involvement, and is not part of the standard initial DMARD regimen recommended in current RA treatment guidelines. Why the other options are correct (used as first-line): A) Sulfasalazine Sulfasalazine is a conventional synthetic DMARD that is effective in treating mild to moderate RA. It is frequently used either as monotherapy or in combination with methotrexate and hydroxychloroquine as part of triple therapy, making it a common and accepted first-line option. B) Methotrexate Methotrexate is considered the cornerstone or anchor drug in RA treatment. It is the most commonly used first-line DMARD due to its effectiveness in controlling disease activity, slowing joint damage, and improving long-term outcomes. It is usually the first drug initiated in moderate to severe RA. C) HCQS (Hydroxychloroquine) Hydroxychloroquine is a mild DMARD often used in early or less severe RA. It is well-tolerated and is commonly prescribed either as monotherapy for mild disease or in combination regimens for more active disease, making it a suitable first-line agent.

questions.text: A patient with proximal muscle weakness, facial rash, and knuckle rash rash as shown in the figure. What is the lesion due to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Dermatomyositis The image shows violaceous, scaly papules on the extensor surfaces of the hand, particularly over the knuckles (metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints), known as Gottron’s papules. These are a hallmark skin finding in dermatomyositis, a connective tissue disorder characterized by proximal muscle weakness (such as difficulty climbing stairs or combing hair) and distinctive skin manifestations like heliotrope rash (violaceous rash around eyes) and Gottron's papules. Dermatomyositis is an autoimmune inflammatory myopathy in which both muscle and skin are involved. The presence of both muscle weakness and characteristic rash clinches the diagnosis. Incorrect Options: A. Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) SLE can present with a malar rash and other cutaneous findings like discoid lesions, but Gottron’s papules are not seen in SLE. Muscle involvement, if present, is usually mild and secondary to inflammation or drugs, not the predominant feature. C. Polymyositis Polymyositis also causes proximal muscle weakness, similar to dermatomyositis, but lacks the cutaneous findings. Gottron’s papules and heliotrope rash are absent in polymyositis, which helps differentiate it from dermatomyositis. D. Sarcoidosis Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous disease that can affect multiple organs, including the skin and muscles, but it does not produce Gottron’s papules or characteristic skin lesions of dermatomyositis. Muscle involvement is rare and not a presenting feature.

questions.text: Pegloticase used for treatment of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Chronic gout Pegloticase is a recombinant uricase enzyme used for the treatment of chronic gout, especially in patients with severe, treatment-refractory cases who do not respond to or cannot tolerate conventional urate-lowering therapies like allopurinol or febuxostat. It works by converting uric acid into allantoin, a water-soluble compound that is more easily excreted by the kidneys. Pegloticase is administered intravenously and is particularly effective in rapidly lowering serum uric acid levels and resolving tophi. Because of its potential for infusion reactions and immunogenicity, it is typically reserved for severe or tophaceous gout that has not responded to other treatments. Incorrect Options: B) Paralytic ileus Pegloticase has no role in the management of paralytic ileus, which is a gastrointestinal motility disorder often managed with supportive care, bowel rest, or prokinetic agents—not urate-lowering drugs. C) Psoriatic arthritis Psoriatic arthritis is an autoimmune inflammatory arthritis treated with NSAIDs, DMARDs, or biologics. Pegloticase does not target the inflammatory pathways involved in psoriatic arthritis and is not used in its treatment. D) Rheumatoid arthritis Rheumatoid arthritis is managed with DMARDs (like methotrexate) and biologic agents targeting specific inflammatory mediators. Pegloticase does not affect these inflammatory mechanisms and is not indicated for rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: A patient of RTA presents in emergency with inability to speak. On examination, the patient was moaning with inability to speak but patient was able to understand what he wanted to speak. Which of the following marked area of brain is involved in this?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) B The patient presents with inability to speak (expressive aphasia) but is able to comprehend language, indicating a lesion in Broca’s area. Broca’s area is classically located in the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere (usually left hemisphere for right-handed individuals). This area is responsible for the motor planning of speech. In the image, the area marked B corresponds to the inferior frontal gyrus, identifying Broca’s area as the region involved. Damage to this area leads to non-fluent, expressive aphasia, where the patient understands spoken language but cannot articulate speech fluently. Patients often produce halting speech or may be limited to moaning or short phrases despite intact comprehension. Incorrect Options: A. A This area appears to correspond with the superior frontal gyrus. While it plays a role in motor planning and cognitive functions, it is not responsible for speech production. Lesions here would not produce the characteristic expressive aphasia seen in this case. C. C This region likely indicates the parietal lobe, possibly near the supramarginal or angular gyrus, involved in language comprehension (Wernicke's area). A lesion here would lead to receptive aphasia (fluent but meaningless speech), not expressive aphasia. D. D This area is in the temporo-occipital junction or cerebellar region, not associated with speech production or comprehension. Cerebellar lesions may cause dysarthria or coordination issues, but not aphasia.

choices.text: Endothelial injury of vessel due to HTN

questions.text: Berry aneurysm most commonly occurs due to:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Tunica media defect Berry aneurysms, also known as saccular aneurysms, are the most common type of intracranial aneurysms and are frequently found at arterial branch points in the Circle of Willis. The most widely accepted cause is a congenital defect in the tunica media, the muscular middle layer of the arterial wall. This defect weakens the vessel wall at bifurcation points, making it susceptible to ballooning out under arterial pressure. Although these defects are often congenital, aneurysm formation may be precipitated or worsened by hemodynamic stress, such as hypertension or atherosclerosis. However, the initiating factor remains the structural weakness of the tunica media, which fails to provide adequate support to the vessel wall. Incorrect Options: A) Endothelial injury of vessel due to HTN Hypertension can contribute to the growth and rupture of a berry aneurysm by increasing intraluminal pressure, but it is not the primary cause. The initial lesion is a structural defect in the tunica media, not endothelial injury. C) Endothelial layer defect The endothelial layer lines the interior of blood vessels and while its dysfunction can play a role in vascular diseases, berry aneurysms are not primarily caused by endothelial defects. The key problem lies deeper in the muscular wall (tunica media). D) Adventitia defect The adventitia is the outermost layer of the vessel and plays a minor role in aneurysm pathogenesis. A defect here is not typically associated with berry aneurysm formation.

choices.text: SACD (Subacute combined degeneration os spinal cord)

questions.text: Patient had recurrent optic neuritis of both eyes with Extensive Transverse Myelitis. Visual acuity in Right eye is 6/60 & visual acuity in Left eye 6/18. Patient showed 50% response to steroids. Diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) NMO (Neuromyelitis Optica) The correct diagnosis is Neuromyelitis Optica (NMO), also known as Devic’s disease, an autoimmune demyelinating condition that primarily affects the optic nerves and spinal cord. The hallmark features include recurrent optic neuritis (leading to visual impairment) and longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis (LETM), which is characterized by inflammation extending over three or more vertebral segments. This patient presents with bilateral optic neuritis and extensive myelitis, which are classical features of NMO. Additionally, a partial response to steroids is consistent with the typical course of NMO, which often shows incomplete or partial improvement with corticosteroid therapy. Diagnostic confirmation would involve testing for aquaporin-4 (AQP4-IgG) antibodies, which are often positive in NMO patients. Incorrect Options: B) SACD (Subacute Combined Degeneration of the spinal cord) SACD is due to vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to involvement of the posterior columns and corticospinal tracts. It presents with sensory ataxia, paresthesia, spasticity, and positive Romberg’s sign, but optic neuritis and acute transverse myelitis are not typical features. C) Posterior cerebral artery (PCA) stroke PCA stroke may lead to homonymous hemianopia and visual field defects, not optic neuritis or transverse myelitis. Additionally, it is an acute vascular event and would not present with recurrent bilateral optic neuritis or spinal cord involvement. D) Neurosyphilis Neurosyphilis can cause a wide range of neurological symptoms, including optic atrophy, but recurrent optic neuritis with extensive myelitis is not typical. The presentation in this case is much more characteristic of NMO.

questions.text: True/False guarding a patient presents with right sided hemiparesis and aphasia since 1 hour- A. Tenectplase not started if CT scan normal B. Tenectplase not started before MRI if CT scan normal C. rTPA given when BP < 185/100 D. rTPA given in a patient taking warfarin with INR 1.4 E. Dual antiplatelet therapy immediately
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A) A-True, B-False, C-True, D-True, E-False ? This is a clinical scenario of an acute ischemic stroke with classic symptoms (right hemiparesis and aphasia), presenting within the golden window (<4.5 hours) for thrombolysis. The goal is to evaluate the timing and safety of thrombolytic therapy (Tenecteplase or rTPA), and appropriate use of antiplatelet agents. A. Tenecteplase not started if CT scan normal — TRUE This statement is true in a specific clinical context. A normal CT scan in the setting of acute stroke does not rule out ischemia, as early infarcts may not yet be visible. However, Tenecteplase is only started after excluding hemorrhage on CT, and confirming diagnosis of ischemic stroke based on clinical findings. So, a normal CT does not justify not starting Tenecteplase — hence the tricky wording. This is interpreted as true if "not started just based on CT being normal" is implied. B. Tenecteplase not started before MRI if CT scan normal — FALSE This is false because non-contrast CT is sufficient to rule out hemorrhage in acute stroke. MRI is not mandatory before initiating thrombolysis. Tenecteplase or rTPA can be given based on CT findings and clinical suspicion. C. rTPA given when BP < 185/100 — TRUE Correct. Blood pressure must be lowered to <185/100 mmHg before administering thrombolysis to reduce the risk of intracerebral hemorrhage. This is a standard contraindication to thrombolysis if not controlled. D. rTPA given in a patient taking warfarin with INR 1.4 — TRUE True. Thrombolysis with rTPA is allowed if the INR is ≤1.7. An INR of 1.4 is within the safe range. E. Dual antiplatelet therapy immediately — FALSE This is false because dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) (aspirin + clopidogrel) is not started immediately in the setting of thrombolysis. It is only considered later in selected cases with minor stroke or TIA, and never immediately post-thrombolysis due to bleeding risk.

choices.text: EEG is mandatory for diagnosis of epilepsy
EEG is used for diagnosis of frontal lobe seizures
In abscence EEG will show generalized spike and wave pattern
10% of normal people also show epileptiform discharge on EEG

questions.text: Which of the following is false ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) EEG is mandatory for diagnosis of epilepsy A) EEG is mandatory for diagnosis of epilepsy — False This is the false statement, hence the correct answer to the question. Epilepsy is a clinical diagnosis primarily based on a detailed history of recurrent unprovoked seizures. While electroencephalography (EEG) is a valuable tool to support the diagnosis and to help classify seizure types, it is not mandatory. A significant number of patients with epilepsy may have normal EEG findings in the interictal (between seizures) period. Furthermore, treatment decisions are often made based on the clinical context, even if the EEG is inconclusive or normal. Incorrect Options: B) EEG is used for diagnosis of frontal lobe seizures — True This statement is true. EEG plays an important role in evaluating focal seizures, including those originating in the frontal lobes. Though frontal lobe seizures can be difficult to detect on EEG due to deep-seated foci or rapid spread, the tool is still useful, particularly with video EEG monitoring, in capturing these events. C) In absence seizures, EEG will show generalized spike and wave pattern — True This is true. Typical absence seizures, most commonly seen in children, are associated with a classic 3 Hz generalized spike-and-wave pattern on EEG. This finding is often used to make or confirm the diagnosis. D) 10% of normal people also show epileptiform discharge on EEG — True This is also true. Though less commonly quoted, studies have shown that up to 1–4% and sometimes even up to 10% of healthy individuals without epilepsy can show epileptiform discharges on EEG. This highlights why EEG findings must always be interpreted in clinical context, and not used in isolation to diagnose epilepsy.

questions.text: Eye hand coordination is the function of which lobe
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Parietal The parietal lobe plays a critical role in eye-hand coordination, which is part of visuomotor integration. The parietal lobe integrates sensory information from different modalities (visual, spatial, tactile) and is essential for tasks that require spatial awareness, depth perception, and guiding hand movements based on visual input. The posterior parietal cortex, in particular, helps in translating visual information into motor commands—essential for coordinated movements like reaching or grasping based on where the eyes are looking. Incorrect Options: A) Frontal The frontal lobe is primarily responsible for motor planning, executive functions, and voluntary movement initiation. While it contributes to movement, coordination between eye and hand based on sensory input is not its primary role. C) Temporal The temporal lobe is involved in auditory processing, language comprehension, and memory functions, not in spatial coordination or visuomotor integration. D) Occipital The occipital lobe is responsible for visual perception and processing. While it receives and processes visual input, it does not integrate this with motor functions like eye-hand coordination. That integration is done by the parietal lobe.

questions.text: Which of the following is used in acute treatment of cluster headache?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) SC sumatriptan Subcutaneous (SC) sumatriptan is the most effective and fastest-acting option for the acute treatment of cluster headaches. Cluster headaches are characterized by severe, unilateral periorbital pain with autonomic features, and they require rapid-acting treatments due to their sudden onset and short duration. SC sumatriptan (6 mg) provides relief typically within 10–15 minutes, making it highly suitable for aborting an acute cluster attack. It is FDA-approved for this indication and is the first-line treatment in many guidelines. Incorrect Options : A) Oral sumatriptan Although sumatriptan is effective for migraines, oral administration is too slow for cluster headache due to its delayed onset of action. Cluster headaches are short-lived, and the time taken for oral absorption makes it ineffective for acute relief. C) Oxygen at 6 L/min Oxygen therapy is indeed used for cluster headaches, but the flow rate matters. A 6 L/min flow is often insufficient for therapeutic benefit. Effective relief requires high-flow oxygen. D) Oxygen at 8 L/min Although better than 6 L/min, even 8 L/min may be suboptimal. Most guidelines recommend 12–15 L/min of 100% oxygen via a non-rebreather mask for acute cluster headache treatment. So, 8 L/min is not considered standard.

questions.text: Which of the following is the preferred drug for treatment of primary progressive multiple sclerosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ocrelizumab Ocrelizumab is the only FDA-approved disease-modifying therapy (DMT) specifically indicated for Primary Progressive Multiple Sclerosis (PPMS). It is a monoclonal antibody targeting CD20-positive B cells, which are believed to play a central role in the pathogenesis of MS. In clinical trials (particularly the ORATORIO study), ocrelizumab significantly reduced disability progression in patients with PPMS, making it the treatment of choice for this subtype of MS. Its approval marked a breakthrough, as effective treatments for PPMS were previously lacking. Incorrect Options A) Natalizumab Natalizumab is a monoclonal antibody against α4-integrin, effective in relapsing forms of MS, particularly relapsing-remitting MS (RRMS). It is not approved for PPMS and has no proven efficacy in this subtype. C) Alemtuzumab Alemtuzumab is a monoclonal antibody targeting CD52 and is used in relapsing MS. It is not indicated for PPMS and has significant risk of autoimmune complications, limiting its use to selected RRMS cases. D) None of the above This is incorrect because ocrelizumab (option B) is definitely approved and preferred for treating PPMS.

choices.text: If a and c are correct
If b and d are correct
If all four (a, b, c & d are correct)

questions.text: With regards to JME: A. Polygenic inheritance B. Valproate should be avoided C. Lamotrigine decreases the incidence of myoclonus D. BZD alone can treat myoclonic jerks
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) If A is correct A. Polygenic inheritance Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy is believed to have a polygenic or complex inheritance pattern, involving multiple genes contributing to its development. Though some familial forms show autosomal dominant traits, the overall inheritance is better described as polygenic, supported by genetic association studies. Incorrect Options: B. Valproate should be avoided Valproate is actually the first-line and most effective drug for JME. It controls all seizure types seen in JME—myoclonic jerks, generalized tonic-clonic seizures (GTCS), and absence seizures. It should not be avoided in general, except in females of reproductive age, where its use is limited due to high teratogenic risk. C. Lamotrigine decreases the incidence of myoclonus Lamotrigine is not ideal for JME, and in some cases, it may actually worsen myoclonic jerks. It is considered a less effective option compared to valproate or levetiracetam. D. Benzodiazepines alone can treat myoclonic jerks Benzodiazepines like clonazepam can reduce myoclonic jerks symptomatically, but they are not sufficient alone to manage the full spectrum of seizures in JME. They are usually used as adjuncts rather than monotherapy.

questions.text: A known case of syphilis unable to walk with eyes closed and walks with stamping the foot on ground. Which tract involved
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Dorsal column The dorsal column (posterior column) of the spinal cord carries proprioception, fine touch, and vibration sense. In tabes dorsalis, a late manifestation of neurosyphilis, the dorsal columns degenerate, leading to loss of position sense. This causes: Positive Romberg's sign (instability with eyes closed) Stamping gait — the patient stomps feet to generate vibrations for feedback due to lack of proprioception. These findings match the clinical description in the question. Hence, dorsal column involvement is the correct answer. Incorrect Options: A) Vestibulocerebellar tract This tract is involved in balance and coordination, especially in relation to head position and eye movements. Lesions here may cause vertigo, nystagmus, or ataxia, but not stamping gait or Romberg’s sign. B) Spinocerebellar tract The spinocerebellar tract carries unconscious proprioception to the cerebellum. Lesions cause ataxia, but the patient’s balance does not worsen with eyes closed, so Romberg’s sign is negative. This doesn't fit the clinical picture. D) Lateral spinothalamic tract This tract carries pain and temperature sensations. Its involvement leads to loss of these sensations, not proprioception, and hence won’t cause stamping gait or Romberg’s sign.

questions.text: A patient presents with history of urinary incontinence with soiling of clothes and he has no guilt of the above action. Which of the following lobes are affected?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Frontal lobe The frontal lobe, specifically the medial frontal micturition center (located near the superior frontal gyrus), is responsible for the voluntary control of bladder function. It also contributes to executive function, behavior regulation, and social awareness. When the frontal lobe is damaged, patients may present with: Urinary incontinence due to loss of voluntary control Apathetic behavior, lack of insight, or emotional blunting (explaining the lack of guilt or concern) A classic feature is the "frontal lobe incontinence" seen in normal pressure hydrocephalus or frontal lobe tumors/infarcts Hence, the patient's symptoms point to a frontal lobe lesion. Incorrect Options: B) Locus coeruleus The locus coeruleus is located in the pons and is primarily involved in arousal, stress response, and attention, via norepinephrine release. It has no direct role in bladder control or behavioral regulation related to incontinence. C) Temporal lobe The temporal lobe is mainly involved in auditory processing, memory, and emotion (via the limbic system). While damage here may affect memory or mood, it does not typically cause urinary incontinence or lack of behavioral awareness regarding it. D) Parietal lobe The parietal lobe processes sensory input and is involved in spatial awareness and body sensation. Lesions here may cause sensory neglect, but not urinary incontinence or emotional indifference.

questions.text: A patient has Recurrent optic neuritis with myelitis and episode were relieved by steroid use. Which is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Neuromyelitis optica Neuromyelitis Optica (NMO), also known as Devic’s disease, is a demyelinating autoimmune disorder that primarily affects the optic nerves and the spinal cord. Key clinical features include: Recurrent optic neuritis → causing vision loss Transverse myelitis → often longitudinally extensive, causing limb weakness, bladder/bowel dysfunction Good response to steroids in acute attacks Anti-AQP4 (Aquaporin-4) antibodies are often positive This clinical pattern of recurrent optic neuritis and myelitis with steroid responsiveness is classic for NMO. ? Incorrect Options: A) Hereditary spastic paraplegia This is a genetic neurodegenerative disorder that causes progressive lower limb spasticity and weakness, but it does not present with optic neuritis or respond to steroids. C) Subacute combined degeneration Caused by vitamin B12 deficiency, this condition affects the dorsal columns and corticospinal tracts, leading to proprioceptive loss, ataxia, and spasticity, but optic neuritis is rare, and the disease does not typically respond to steroids. D) Parkinson syndrome This involves dopaminergic neuron degeneration, presenting with bradykinesia, tremor, rigidity, and postural instability. It does not involve optic neuritis or spinal cord inflammation, nor is it responsive to steroids.

questions.text: A brain cut section as shown below, has injury in the marked area. Which of the following will happen when the marked structure is damaged?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Urinary incontinence The marked green area in the image corresponds to the medial aspect of the frontal lobe, specifically the paracentral lobule, which includes part of the primary motor cortex controlling the lower limbs and perineum, including voluntary control of micturition (urination). Damage to this area, such as from trauma, stroke, or a frontal lobe lesion, can impair the voluntary control of the bladder, leading to urge incontinence or reflex bladder. This is often seen in frontal lobe syndromes, normal pressure hydrocephalus, or parasagittal meningiomas. Incorrect Options: B. Bowel incontinence Although the paracentral lobule has some role in pelvic floor control, bowel continence is more complex and involves multiple regions, including the insula, anterior cingulate, and spinal pathways. Bowel incontinence is not as directly linked to this region as urinary incontinence. C. Paraesthesia peri-anally This symptom is more specific to cauda equina syndrome or sacral spinal cord lesions, not a cerebral lesion like the one shown. D. Gait apraxia Gait apraxia occurs due to damage to the frontal lobe (especially medial frontal cortex), corpus callosum, or subcortical structures, but it’s more associated with supplementary motor area or periventricular white matter lesions, not specifically the paracentral lobule.

choices.text: No intervention as CT is normal

questions.text: A 55-year-old person brought to the casualty with a history of TIA and now presents with left sided facial weakness for 1 hour. CT is clear, BP – 160/110 mm HG. What is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Start IV thrombolysis This patient is showing acute onset of focal neurological deficit (left-sided facial weakness) suggestive of an ischemic stroke, and he presented within 1 hour of symptom onset, which is well within the 4.5-hour window for thrombolysis. Non-contrast CT is done to rule out hemorrhage, not to detect early infarction (which may not appear initially). Since CT is clear (i.e., no hemorrhage) and there are no contraindications (BP <185/110 mmHg is acceptable, and his is 160/110), the patient qualifies for IV thrombolysis, typically with rTPA (alteplase) or tenecteplase. Early thrombolysis improves outcomes by restoring perfusion to ischemic brain tissue. Incorrect Options: B) Aspirin and clopidogrel Dual antiplatelet therapy is indicated in minor stroke or high-risk TIA, not in patients who are candidates for thrombolysis. Giving antiplatelets before thrombolysis increases the risk of hemorrhage. C) Manage blood pressure The BP of 160/110 mmHg is within the acceptable range for thrombolysis (<185/110 mmHg). Lowering BP at this point may reduce cerebral perfusion. Thrombolysis should not be delayed just to manage BP in this case. D) No intervention as CT is normal A normal CT does not rule out ischemic stroke, especially early on. Doing nothing would miss the critical window for thrombolysis and allow further brain damage.

choices.text: Sensory loss at a specific level

questions.text: Which of the following clinical presentation will not occur due to lesion in spinal cord
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Crossed hemiplegia Crossed hemiplegia refers to a neurological pattern where there is: Ipsilateral cranial nerve palsy (e.g., facial or oculomotor weakness), and Contralateral hemiparesis of the limbs. This occurs due to brainstem lesions, especially involving the midbrain, pons, or medulla, where cranial nerve nuclei and descending corticospinal tracts are both located in close proximity. The spinal cord, however, does not contain cranial nerve nuclei, and thus cannot produce crossed hemiplegia. Therefore, this presentation is not associated with spinal cord pathology. Incorrect Options: B) Bladder involvement Spinal cord lesions, especially in the thoracic, lumbar, or sacral regions, can disrupt descending control over the bladder, leading to urinary retention, urgency, or incontinence. Hence, this is a common feature of spinal cord pathology. C) LMN and UMN both lesions A spinal cord lesion can affect: Lower motor neurons (LMNs) at the level of the lesion (anterior horn cells), and Upper motor neurons (UMNs) below the level of the lesion (corticospinal tract disruption). So, a combination of LMN signs at the level and UMN signs below the level is characteristic of spinal cord involvement. D) Sensory loss at a specific level A dermatomal level of sensory loss is a classic sign of spinal cord lesion and helps localize the level of pathology. It results from damage to the ascending sensory tracts (spinothalamic, dorsal columns) or dorsal roots.

questions.text: All the true regarding Brown Sequard syndrome except 1) Complete section of spinal cord 2) Ipsilateral loss of pain and temp 3) Ipsilateral loss of touch and vibration 4) No motor loss 5) Ipsilateral loss of proprioception
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 1, 2, 4 Brown-Séquard syndrome is caused by a hemisection (partial lesion) of the spinal cord, typically due to trauma, tumors, or demyelinating disease. It leads to a distinct pattern of neurological deficits due to disruption of specific tracts: Ipsilateral motor loss (due to corticospinal tract damage) Ipsilateral loss of touch, vibration, proprioception (due to dorsal column involvement) Contralateral loss of pain and temperature (due to crossing spinothalamic tract fibers) So, the statements that are false (i.e., exceptions) are: Complete section of spinal cord → Incorrect: Brown-Séquard involves hemisection, not complete transection. Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature → Incorrect: Pain and temperature are lost contralaterally, not ipsilaterally. No motor loss → Incorrect: There is motor loss ipsilaterally due to corticospinal tract involvement. Hence, options 1, 2, and 4 are not true, making Option A the correct answer. Incorrect Options: B) 1, 2, 3 Statement 3 (Ipsilateral loss of touch and vibration) is true in Brown-Séquard syndrome, because the dorsal columns (which carry touch, vibration, proprioception) ascend ipsilaterally. So including 3 in incorrect statements is wrong. C) 1, 4, 5 Statement 5 (Ipsilateral loss of proprioception) is true, so this option incorrectly includes it as an exception. D) 1, 2, 5 As above, 2 is false (pain/temp loss is contralateral), but 5 is true, so this grouping is incorrect.

questions.text: Tongue fasciculation seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Spinal Muscular Atrophy (SMA) Spinal Muscular Atrophy (SMA) is a lower motor neuron disease affecting the anterior horn cells in the spinal cord. Because of the degeneration of these motor neurons, patients show classic signs of LMN lesions like: Muscle atrophy Hypotonia Areflexia Tongue fasciculations Tongue fasciculations are fine, spontaneous, involuntary muscle twitches seen most commonly in infantile SMA (Werdnig-Hoffmann disease). They are a distinguishing clinical feature and help in differentiating SMA from other neuromuscular conditions. Incorrect Options: B) Myasthenia Gravis (MG) MG is a neuromuscular junction disorder, not a lower motor neuron disease. It leads to fatigable weakness but no muscle atrophy or fasciculations. Tongue fasciculations are not seen. C) Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) DMD is a muscle fiber disorder, not a motor neuron or NMJ issue. It presents with proximal muscle weakness, calf hypertrophy, and Gower’s sign, but not fasciculations, as the motor neurons are intact. D) Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) GBS is an acute demyelinating polyneuropathy affecting peripheral nerves. Though it causes flaccid paralysis, it doesn’t involve the anterior horn cells, so fasciculations are absent.

choices.text: All patients with neurological impairment will show macrocytosis.

questions.text: All are true about subacute combined degeneration of cord (SACD) EXCEPT?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) All patients with neurological impairment will show macrocytosis. While macrocytosis (increased MCV) is a classic hematologic feature of vitamin B12 deficiency, not all patients with neurological manifestations of SACD will have macrocytosis. In fact, neurological symptoms can precede hematologic findings like macrocytic anemia. This makes relying solely on blood counts misleading in some patients. Hence, statement B is false, making it the correct answer to an “EXCEPT” question. Incorrect Options: A) Dorsal & lateral column are involved - True SACD is caused by vitamin B12 deficiency and primarily affects the dorsal columns (responsible for vibration and proprioception) and lateral corticospinal tracts (responsible for motor control), leading to sensory ataxia and spastic paresis. C) Vitamin B12 improves condition - True Early diagnosis and vitamin B12 supplementation can halt disease progression and lead to partial or full neurological recovery, especially if treated before irreversible damage. D) Copper deficiency produces similar symptoms- True Copper deficiency mimics SACD clinically and radiologically, with similar involvement of the dorsal columns and corticospinal tracts. It's important to differentiate the two via serum levels, as management differs.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs are recommended for the treatment of Absence seizure? (Multiple Correct) A. Ethosuximide B. Carbamazepine C. Lamotrigine D. Valproate E. Gabapentin
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A, C, D A) Ethosuximide – First-line treatment for absence seizures, especially in children. It works by inhibiting T-type calcium channels in thalamic neurons, which are involved in the generation of 3 Hz spike-and-wave discharges seen in absence seizures. C) Lamotrigine – Effective against absence seizures, although not typically first-line. It can be used as monotherapy or adjunctive therapy, especially when ethosuximide or valproate are not suitable. D) Valproate – Also considered first-line and particularly effective when absence seizures co-exist with other generalized seizure types (e.g., tonic-clonic). It has broad-spectrum antiepileptic activity, making it a preferred choice in mixed seizure syndromes. Incorrect Options: B) Carbamazepine – Contraindicated in absence seizures. It may worsen absence and other generalized seizure types by exacerbating spike-and-wave discharges. E) Gabapentin – Ineffective in absence seizures. It is more commonly used in focal seizures and neuropathic pain, and has no proven efficacy in treating absence seizures.

choices.text: Antiparasitic drug to be started before steroid.
Steroids to be started before antiparasitic drugs.
Steroids to be given only after stopping antiepileptics.

questions.text: A child with Headache & 1 episode of seizure is admitted to Hospital. On clinical examination there is no focal neurological deficit. On CT(Brain) cystic lesions are seen with scolex inside & surrounding perilesional edema is seen. The child is started on antiepileptics. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Steroids to be started before antiparasitic drugs. This is a classic case of neurocysticercosis, a parasitic CNS infection caused by Taenia solium larvae. CT findings of cystic lesions with scolex and perilesional edema confirm the diagnosis. When antiparasitic therapy (like albendazole or praziquantel) is initiated, it leads to death of the larval cysts, which in turn causes a robust inflammatory response and can worsen cerebral edema and seizures. Therefore, steroids (e.g., dexamethasone or prednisolone) are started before antiparasitic drugs to reduce inflammation and control perilesional edema. This pre-treatment helps in minimizing complications during larval destruction. Incorrect Options : A) Antiparasitic drug to be started before steroid This is not advisable, as it can worsen inflammation and symptoms due to sudden antigen release from dying parasites. C) Only antiepileptics to be given Antiepileptics are essential for seizure control, but they do not treat the underlying parasitic infection. Antiparasitic therapy is also needed, especially when scolex is visible (viable cyst stage), indicating a treatable infection. D) Steroids to be given only after stopping antiepileptics There is no such protocol. Antiepileptics and steroids can and should be co-administered as they address different components of the disease (seizure vs inflammation).

questions.text: Drugs exacerbating MG. (Multiple answers) A. Phenytoin B. Lignocaine C. Digene D. Meropenem E. Dapsone
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A, B Phenytoin and lignocaine are known to exacerbate MG symptoms by impairing neuromuscular transmission. Phenytoin (an anticonvulsant) can worsen muscle weakness in MG by affecting neuromuscular junction function. Lignocaine (local anesthetic) can interfere with neuromuscular transmission and cause transient worsening of muscle weakness in MG patients. Both drugs can reduce the efficiency of acetylcholine signaling, thus aggravating MG. Incorrect Responses: Digene is an antacid and has no effect on neuromuscular transmission or MG symptoms. Meropenem is a broad-spectrum antibiotic, not typically associated with exacerbation of MG. Dapsone is used in certain infections and inflammatory conditions but is not known to worsen MG.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with weight gain & lethargy on investigations her TSH levels are high & T4 levels are low. Likely diagnosis for her clinical condition is: -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hashimoto disease Hashimoto’s thyroiditis is the most common cause of primary hypothyroidism. It is an autoimmune condition where the thyroid gland is destroyed by immune-mediated inflammation, leading to decreased production of thyroid hormones (low T4). As the thyroid hormone levels fall, the pituitary gland compensates by increasing TSH secretion, resulting in high TSH levels. Clinically, this manifests as weight gain, lethargy, cold intolerance, and other hypothyroid symptoms. Incorrect Options : A) Graves’ disease Graves’ disease causes hyperthyroidism, characterized by low TSH (due to negative feedback) and high T4, opposite of the patient’s findings. C) Pituitary dysfunction Pituitary dysfunction causing hypothyroidism (secondary hypothyroidism) typically shows low or normal TSH with low T4, unlike this case where TSH is high. D) Hypoparathyroidism Hypoparathyroidism affects calcium metabolism and does not cause changes in thyroid hormones or TSH.

questions.text: Which of The Following Are Core Clinical Criteria Of Neuromyelitis Optica A. Optic Neuritis B. Area Postrema Syndrome C. Focal Epilepsy D. Acute Diencephalic Syndrome
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A, B, D Neuromyelitis Optica (NMO) is a demyelinating disorder primarily affecting the optic nerves and spinal cord but also involves other specific brain regions. The core clinical criteria of NMO include: Optic Neuritis (A): Inflammation of the optic nerve causing vision loss, a hallmark feature of NMO. Area Postrema Syndrome (B): Characterized by intractable hiccups, nausea, or vomiting due to lesions in the area postrema of the medulla, often seen in NMO. Acute Diencephalic Syndrome (D): Involves hypothalamic or thalamic lesions leading to symptoms like altered consciousness, endocrine abnormalities, or autonomic dysfunction, included in NMO criteria. These symptoms are part of the International Panel for NMO diagnosis and help distinguish NMO from other demyelinating diseases like multiple sclerosis. Incorrect Options : Focal Epilepsy (C): This is not considered a core clinical criterion of NMO. Seizures are rare and not typical features of NMO.

questions.text: A Female With H/O Sharp Pain On One Side Of Body. Even Splashing Water During Dish Washing Cause Sharp Pain . Lacunar Lesion Of Which Area Is Responsible For Her Symptoms ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Thalamus The CT image shows a lacunar infarct, which is a small, deep infarct due to occlusion of penetrating arteries, commonly affecting subcortical structures. The clinical scenario describes a female with sharp, electric-shock-like pain on one side of the body, triggered even by mild stimuli (e.g., water splashing). This classic description matches Dejerine-Roussy syndrome, also known as thalamic pain syndrome. This syndrome is a post-stroke neuropathic pain condition that occurs after a thalamic infarct, especially involving the ventroposterolateral (VPL) or ventroposteromedial (VPM) nuclei — key relay centers for sensory information from the body and face, respectively. Incorrect Options: B. Subthalamus Lesions here more commonly cause hemiballismus (violent, flinging limb movements) and not pain syndromes. C. Caudate Nucleus Primarily involved in cognitive and motor function regulation. Lesions can cause behavioral changes or movement disorders, not classic sensory pain. D. Substantia Nigra Lesions cause Parkinsonian symptoms (tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia) due to dopamine depletion, not pain syndromes.

questions.text: Alpha synucleopathy shown in all except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Alzheimer’s disease Alpha-synucleinopathies are a group of neurodegenerative diseases characterized by abnormal accumulation of alpha-synuclein protein aggregates in neurons or glial cells. These include: Parkinson’s disease (A): Marked by Lewy bodies containing alpha-synuclein in dopaminergic neurons. Lewy body dementia (B): Also features widespread Lewy bodies with alpha-synuclein deposits in the cortex. Multiple system atrophy (C): Characterized by alpha-synuclein accumulation predominantly in oligodendrocytes (glial cytoplasmic inclusions). Incorrect Option: Alzheimer’s disease (D) Alzheimer’s is primarily an amyloid-beta and tau proteinopathy, not an alpha-synucleinopathy. While there can be some overlap or co-pathology, alpha-synuclein is not the defining feature of Alzheimer’s disease.

questions.text: A patient presented with status TIA.which of the parameters would suggest higher risk of him developing stroke in future according to ABCD2 Scoring?? A). Age140 C). Duration 5 mins D). Diabetes Choose according to options
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Only B and D correct The ABCD² score is a clinical tool used to predict the risk of stroke after a transient ischemic attack (TIA). It consists of five parameters: Age ≥ 60 years (not < 60) → 1 point Blood Pressure ≥ 140/90 mmHg (usually measured as systolic >140 or diastolic >90) → 1 point Clinical features (e.g., unilateral weakness, speech disturbance) Duration of TIA symptoms: ≥60 minutes → 2 points 10-59 minutes → 1 point <10 minutes → 0 points Diabetes Mellitus → 1 point In this question: Age < 60 years (A) is not a risk factor; age ≥ 60 is relevant. Systolic BP > 140 (B) is a risk factor. Duration 5 minutes (C) is less than 10 minutes, so it scores 0, not a high-risk factor. Diabetes (D) is a risk factor. Hence, only B and D are correct in indicating a higher risk for stroke. Incorrect Options: A (Age < 60) is incorrect because risk increases with age ≥ 60. C (Duration 5 minutes) is too short to be considered high risk. Duration ≥ 10 minutes is significant.

questions.text: Left sided hemiplegia. Internal capsule injury on the right side at?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Posterior limb The posterior limb of the internal capsule contains corticospinal fibers which are responsible for voluntary motor control of the contralateral body. An injury to the right posterior limb would affect the descending corticospinal tracts, resulting in left-sided hemiplegia. This area is highly vulnerable to lacunar infarcts and small vessel strokes, often due to hypertension. Because the corticospinal tract is somatotopically organized here, even small lesions can cause profound motor deficits on the contralateral side. Incorrect Options: B) Anterior limb Contains frontopontine and thalamocortical fibers. Lesions here affect cognition and behavior, not motor control. C) Sublentiform part Contains auditory radiations. Lesions here would affect hearing, not motor function. D) Retrolentiform part Contains optic radiations. Damage here results in visual field defects (e.g., contralateral homonymous hemianopia), not hemiplegia.

questions.text: A patient misses everything on the left side, including drawing the petals of a flower only on the right side, clock numbers on right side, shaving only the right half of the face, eating from only the right side. The site of lesion
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Right posterior parietal cortex Right posterior parietal cortex lesion causes left hemispatial neglect, a classic neurobehavioral syndrome. Patients with this condition ignore or are unaware of stimuli on the left side, despite having intact vision. Common signs include: Shaving only the right side of the face Drawing only the right side of an object (e.g., clock, flower) Eating only from the right side of the plate Failing to respond to people or objects on the left This phenomenon is due to the right parietal lobe's dominant role in spatial attention, especially for both left and right visual fields, while the left parietal lobe primarily attends to the right field only. So, a right-sided lesion leads to neglect of the left side. Incorrect Options: B) Left parietal cortex A left parietal lesion may cause language deficits (in a left-dominant brain) or right-sided neglect (rare), but not left-sided neglect, which is more severe and typically associated with right parietal lesions. C) Right temporal cortex The temporal lobe is more associated with auditory processing and memory. It does not primarily control spatial awareness, so lesions here are less likely to produce hemispatial neglect. D) Right frontal cortex Frontal lobe lesions may affect motor planning and personality, not spatial attention in the same way the posterior parietal lobe does.

questions.text: Which of the following is a C/I to thrombolysis in a patient presenting with stroke?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) BP >185/110 BP >185/110 mmHg is a contraindication to thrombolysis with agents like alteplase (rTPA). Elevated blood pressure increases the risk of intracerebral hemorrhage, which is a major complication of thrombolysis. Therefore, blood pressure must be lowered to ≤185/110 mmHg before initiating thrombolytic therapy. If BP cannot be controlled to this level, thrombolysis is withheld. Incorrect Options: A) Age > 18 yrs This is not a contraindication; in fact, age ≥18 years is a criterion for thrombolysis eligibility. B) Presenting within 3 hours This is the ideal window for IV thrombolysis. Up to 4.5 hours may be considered in selected patients, but within 3 hours is optimal, not a contraindication. D) MCA edema MCA (middle cerebral artery) edema may be a consequence of a large infarct, but edema alone is not an absolute contraindication. If there's mass effect or herniation, it becomes a concern, but mild edema is not itself a contraindication.

questions.text: Site of lesion in hemiballismus
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Subthalamus Hemiballismus is a rare hyperkinetic movement disorder characterized by violent, flinging, involuntary movements of the limbs, typically on one side of the body. The classic site of lesion responsible for hemiballismus is the contralateral subthalamic nucleus (of Luys), a part of the basal ganglia circuitry. The subthalamic nucleus normally inhibits movement by exciting the internal globus pallidus, which in turn inhibits the thalamus. When the subthalamic nucleus is damaged (commonly by a small lacunar stroke), this inhibitory control is lost, resulting in excessive, involuntary motor activity—i.e., hemiballismus. Incorrect Options: B) Globus pallidus Lesions here can cause other movement disorders, such as dystonia or Parkinsonism-like symptoms, but not typically hemiballismus. C) Caudate Damage to the caudate nucleus is associated more with cognitive and behavioral disturbances (e.g., in Huntington's disease), not hemiballismus. D) Putamen Involvement of the putamen may cause chorea or dystonia, but not the classical flinging movements of hemiballismus.

questions.text: A patient with type 2 diabetes presented with chest pain and palpitations. Diagnosed as NSTEMI. Which of the following will be treatment options
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Aspirin + Clopidogrel + LMWH In Non-ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction (NSTEMI), the standard treatment includes antiplatelet agents and anticoagulants to prevent further thrombus formation and reduce the risk of progression to full-thickness infarction. The recommended management includes: Aspirin: Irreversibly inhibits COX-1 in platelets, reducing thromboxane A2 production and platelet aggregation. Clopidogrel: A P2Y12 receptor antagonist that works synergistically with aspirin to further inhibit platelet aggregation. LMWH (Low Molecular Weight Heparin): An anticoagulant that inhibits clot formation by enhancing antithrombin III activity. It's commonly used in NSTEMI to prevent propagation of the thrombus. Therefore, the combination of aspirin + clopidogrel + LMWH is standard evidence-based management for NSTEMI and provides the best balance of antithrombotic protection. Incorrect Options: A) Aspirin While essential, aspirin alone is not sufficient in the management of NSTEMI. Dual antiplatelet therapy is more effective. B) Aspirin + Clopidogrel This is an important combination (dual antiplatelet therapy), but without anticoagulation (like LMWH), it's incomplete management for NSTEMI. D) Thrombolytics Thrombolytic therapy is not indicated in NSTEMI. It is reserved for ST-elevation MI (STEMI). Administering thrombolytics in NSTEMI is not only unnecessary but may increase the risk of bleeding.

questions.text: A boy c/o palpitations. ECG showed coved ST elevation. Likely diagnosis
questions.solution: Brugada Syndrome The ECG strip shown reveals a coved-type ST segment elevation in the right precordial leads (V1–V3) followed by an inverted T wave. This is characteristic of the Type 1 Brugada pattern, which is diagnostic for Brugada syndrome in the right clinical context. Brugada syndrome is a genetic channelopathy (usually due to SCN5A mutations affecting sodium channels) and presents with: Palpitations Syncope Sudden cardiac death, especially in young males Characteristic ECG changes without structural heart disease Incorrect Options: A. STEMI (ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction) STEMI causes diffuse ST elevation typically associated with symptoms like chest pain and elevated cardiac enzymes. The ST elevation in Brugada is localized to V1–V3 with a coved appearance, not seen in typical STEMI. B. Early Repolarization Seen in young healthy individuals, this shows notched or slurred J-point elevation, mainly in lateral leads (V4–V6), not the coved ST elevation in V1–V3. D. ARVD (Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Dysplasia) ARVD can present with palpitations and right ventricular arrhythmias, but ECG typically shows epsilon waves, T wave inversions in V1–V3, not the coved ST elevation.

questions.text: Identify the disorder
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Acromegaly The image shows a man with coarse facial features, broad nose, prominent jaw (prognathism), thickened lips, and enlarged facial bones. These are classic features of acromegaly, a disorder caused by excess growth hormone (GH), usually due to a pituitary adenoma. It occurs after epiphyseal fusion, hence results in soft tissue and bone overgrowth, rather than increased height. Key clinical features of acromegaly include: Coarsening of facial features Enlarged hands and feet (increased ring/shoe size) Prognathism (prominent jaw) Frontal bossing Macroglossia (enlarged tongue) Deep voice Hyperhidrosis (sweating) Associated complications: diabetes, hypertension, sleep apnea Incorrect Options: B. Cushing Syndrome This causes moon facies, central obesity, buffalo hump, and purple striae, not the coarse facial changes seen here. C. Hypothyroidism Presents with puffy face, dry skin, hoarseness, weight gain, and bradycardia, not prominent bony overgrowth or coarse features. D. Hyperthyroidism Presents with exophthalmos, goiter, weight loss, and fine tremors, not the facial and skeletal changes typical of acromegaly.

questions.text: Most common cause of hypercalcemia in hospitalized patients is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Malignancy The most common cause of hypercalcemia in hospitalized (inpatient) patients is malignancy. This is a well-established clinical observation supported by hospital-based studies. Malignancy-related hypercalcemia occurs due to several mechanisms: PTHrP (Parathyroid hormone-related peptide) secretion by tumors (most common) Osteolytic bone metastases (e.g., breast cancer, multiple myeloma) Vitamin D–mediated mechanisms (e.g., in lymphomas) It often presents acutely and severely in hospitalized patients and can be life-threatening if not recognized promptly. Incorrect Options: B) Parathyroid adenoma This is the most common cause of hypercalcemia in the general (outpatient) population, due to primary hyperparathyroidism. However, it tends to cause mild and chronic hypercalcemia, often asymptomatic, and is more commonly detected on routine screening. C) Parathyroid hyperplasia Less common than adenoma, this also causes primary hyperparathyroidism but is rarely seen as a cause of acute hypercalcemia in hospitalized settings. D) [Blank option] Since no valid option is provided, it is not considered in the evaluation.

questions.text: 40 year old female c/o symmetrical joint pains with morning stiffness of hands and ankle. Likely diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Rheumatoid arthritis The presentation of symmetrical joint pains with morning stiffness especially involving small joints such as the hands and ankles in a 40-year-old female is highly characteristic of Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA). RA is a chronic autoimmune inflammatory arthritis that: Affects women more commonly. Typically presents in the third to fifth decade of life. Causes symmetrical joint involvement, especially of the MCP, PIP joints, wrists, and ankles. Morning stiffness >30 minutes is a classic symptom due to synovial inflammation. Incorrect Options: A) Gout (Asymmetrical) Gout usually presents as acute, monoarticular, asymmetrical arthritis, often affecting the first MTP joint (podagra). It’s rarely symmetrical and typically affects men more than women. B) Osteoarthritis OA is more mechanical and degenerative in nature. It usually: Affects older individuals (>50 years), Causes asymmetrical joint pain, Morning stiffness is brief (<30 minutes), Commonly involves weight-bearing joints and DIP joints, sparing MCPs. C) Psoriatic arthritis Can be symmetrical or asymmetrical, but: Often associated with skin psoriasis, Has features like dactylitis (sausage digits) and nail changes, May involve axial skeleton. The absence of skin lesions or typical features makes RA more likely in this case.

questions.text: ABG analysis pH 7.28 ↓ Paco2-80 mmHg ↑ HCO3-28 mmol/L ↑
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Respiratory acidosis This arterial blood gas (ABG) report shows: pH = 7.28 → Acidemia (normal: 7.35–7.45) PaCO? = 80 mmHg → ↑ Elevated CO? (normal: 35–45 mmHg) HCO?? = 28 mmol/L → ↑ Elevated bicarbonate (normal: 22–26 mmol/L) These findings are consistent with primary respiratory acidosis. Here's why: The low pH indicates an acidic state. The very high PaCO? is the primary driver of acidosis → indicates hypoventilation, a hallmark of respiratory acidosis. The HCO?? is elevated, showing that metabolic compensation has started but has not normalized the pH, meaning the body is partially compensating. Since pH is still <7.35, it is not fully compensated. Incorrect Options: B) Fully compensated 7.35 Incorrect because the pH is 7.28, not within the normal range (7.35–7.45). In full compensation, pH would be normalized. C) Partially compensated 17.35 Incorrect due to the incorrect pH reference (17.35 is non-physiological) and confusion in terminology. Also, this pH is not even close to any realistic value. D) Uncompensated Incorrect because HCO?? is elevated, showing that the kidneys have started compensating, so it is not uncompensated.

questions.text: Ulcerative colitis with 3 episodes of bloody stools/day.Next line of treatment
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 5-ASA (5-Aminosalicylic acid). In a patient with mild to moderate ulcerative colitis—such as one presenting with 3 episodes of bloody stools per day—5-ASA (mesalamine) is considered the first-line treatment. It is an anti-inflammatory drug that acts topically on the colonic mucosa and is highly effective in inducing and maintaining remission in mild to moderate disease. Depending on the extent of the disease (proctitis, left-sided, or extensive), it may be given orally, rectally, or in combination. Incorrect Options: B) Budesonide Budesonide is a corticosteroid with high first-pass metabolism and fewer systemic side effects. However, it is generally used in Crohn’s disease, particularly for ileocecal involvement, rather than in ulcerative colitis. It is not the first-line agent for UC with mild symptoms. C) Prednisolone Prednisolone is a systemic corticosteroid used in moderate to severe UC or when the patient fails to respond to 5-ASA therapy. In this case, with only 3 episodes of bloody stools/day, the disease is mild, so systemic steroids are not immediately indicated. D) Azathioprine Azathioprine is an immunomodulator used mainly for maintenance therapy or in steroid-dependent or steroid-refractory disease. It is not used for induction of remission, especially not in mild cases, due to its slow onset of action.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetes is approved for heart failure
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Empagliflozin. Empagliflozin is a SGLT2 inhibitor that has shown significant cardiovascular benefits, particularly in reducing hospitalization for heart failure and cardiovascular mortality in patients with type 2 diabetes. The EMPA-REG OUTCOME trial demonstrated that empagliflozin reduced the risk of cardiovascular death, all-cause mortality, and hospitalization for heart failure. Based on this evidence, empagliflozin has been approved not only for glycemic control but also for use in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), even in those without diabetes. Incorrect Options: A) Linagliptin Linagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor, and while it is weight neutral and has a low risk of hypoglycemia, it has not demonstrated a clear benefit in reducing heart failure hospitalizations. Some other drugs in this class (like saxagliptin) have even been associated with increased risk of heart failure. B) Repaglinide Repaglinide is a meglitinide class drug that increases insulin secretion. It has no proven cardiovascular benefits and is not recommended in patients with heart failure due to the risk of hypoglycemia and lack of outcome data. D) Bromocriptine Bromocriptine is a dopamine agonist approved for glycemic control in diabetes, but it lacks evidence for benefit in heart failure and is not approved for this indication.

questions.text: A patient presented with this following reports: • Serology • HbsAg-negative • Anti Hbc • HbeAg negative • Anti Hbs negative
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Past infection. The serological profile shows: HBsAg-negative (no active hepatitis B virus surface antigen), Anti-HBc positive (indicates exposure to hepatitis B virus core antigen), HBeAg-negative (no active viral replication), Anti-HBs negative (no detectable surface antibody). This profile is most consistent with a past infection. It reflects someone who has been exposed to the virus in the past (anti-HBc positive), but the virus is no longer actively replicating (HBsAg negative, HBeAg negative), and for some reason, the anti-HBs antibody is not detectable, which can occur in some resolved infections. Incorrect Options: A) Window period In the window period, HBsAg has disappeared but anti-HBs has not yet appeared. During this time, anti-HBc IgM would be positive. Since this question does not specify the IgM subtype, and given other markers, window period cannot be confirmed from this profile. C) Chronic infection, inactive carrier An inactive carrier would still be HBsAg positive, indicating the virus is present. In this case, the patient is HBsAg negative, ruling out chronic infection or carrier state. D) Post vaccinated A vaccinated individual would be positive for anti-HBs only, and negative for anti-HBc, since the vaccine contains only surface antigen. Here, anti-HBc is positive, ruling out vaccination as the cause.

questions.text: Type 1 diabetes with diabetes ketoacidosis.pH-7.2,blood glucose 400 mg/dl. What should be the management
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) IV fluids followed by insulin In Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA), the first priority is fluid resuscitation, not insulin. This is because patients are often significantly dehydrated due to osmotic diuresis caused by hyperglycemia. Step-by-step rationale: IV fluids are started first to restore intravascular volume, improve renal perfusion, and reduce counter-regulatory stress hormones. This initial step also helps lower blood glucose levels even before insulin is given. After initial fluid resuscitation, insulin (usually IV regular insulin) is administered to stop ketogenesis, reduce blood glucose, and correct acidosis. In this case: pH = 7.2 (acidotic) Blood glucose = 400 mg/dL Classic presentation of DKA Incorrect Options: A) Insulin followed by IV fluids Insulin should not be started first, because without fluid resuscitation, insulin may worsen hypovolemia and cause cardiovascular collapse. C) Insulin SC In moderate to severe DKA, IV insulin is the preferred route for fast onset and titration. Subcutaneous insulin is used only in very mild cases or under specific protocols, often in outpatient settings. D) Incomplete/Invalid option

questions.text: Post bilateral adrenalectomy patient developed hyperpigmentation of fingers. What is the likely diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Nelson syndrome Nelson syndrome occurs as a complication after bilateral adrenalectomy, typically performed for Cushing's disease. Once the adrenal glands are removed, there is a loss of negative feedback on the pituitary gland, leading to increased ACTH production by a pituitary corticotroph adenoma. The excess ACTH stimulates melanocyte-stimulating hormone (MSH) due to a shared precursor (POMC), causing hyperpigmentation, often seen in fingers, oral mucosa, or skin folds. Incorrect Options: A) Conn's syndrome (primary hyperaldosteronism) This condition is due to excess aldosterone, not ACTH. It presents with hypertension and hypokalemia, not hyperpigmentation. B) Addison’s disease (primary adrenal insufficiency) While Addison’s can cause hyperpigmentation, it's not typically seen post-bilateral adrenalectomy (unless the term was used loosely). Also, Addison’s is a primary adrenal failure, not a post-surgical complication.

questions.text: Suspected meninigits • CSF fluid • TLC high with lymphocyte predominance • Glucose 20 mg/dl (blood glucose 140 mg/dl) • Proteins 80 mg/dl
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Tubercular Tubercular meningitis is a chronic meningitis that typically shows the following cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) findings: Total Leukocyte Count (TLC) high with lymphocytic predominance – TBM often shows lymphocytic pleocytosis. Low glucose levels – CSF glucose of 20 mg/dL is very low, especially with a corresponding blood glucose of 140 mg/dL (normally, CSF glucose is about 2/3 of blood glucose, i.e., ~90 mg/dL in this case). Protein elevated (80 mg/dL) – TBM usually has moderate to markedly increased protein. These findings are classical for tubercular meningitis, especially the low glucose + lymphocytic predominance. Incorrect Options: A) Bacterial (Pyogenic) Meningitis Though bacterial meningitis also shows low glucose and high protein, the cell type is neutrophilic, not lymphocytic. This case shows lymphocyte predominance, which rules out typical pyogenic bacterial meningitis. C) Viral Meningitis Viral meningitis typically shows: Lymphocytic predominance Normal or slightly low glucose (not as low as 20 mg/dL) Mildly raised proteins The marked hypoglycorrhachia (low CSF glucose) rules out a viral cause. D) None This CSF pattern clearly suggests a specific etiology: Tubercular meningitis. So, "None" is inappropriate.

questions.text: Metabolic syndrome will include all except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hip circumference Hip circumference is not a component of the diagnostic criteria for metabolic syndrome. While waist circumference (central obesity) is included as a marker of visceral fat and insulin resistance, hip circumference alone is not used in the definition. Metabolic syndrome focuses on central (abdominal) obesity, not overall body size or hip fat distribution. Incorrect Options: B) BP (Blood Pressure) Elevated blood pressure (≥130/85 mmHg) or treatment for hypertension is a defining feature of metabolic syndrome. C) HDL (High-Density Lipoprotein) Low HDL cholesterol is part of the lipid abnormalities in metabolic syndrome. <40 mg/dL in men <50 mg/dL in women D) Blood glucose Elevated fasting blood glucose (≥100 mg/dL) or treatment for hyperglycemia/diabetes is a core criterion.

questions.text: ECG is given the figure. What is the cause
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Third-degree AV Block (Complete Heart Block) The ECG strip in the image shows P waves and QRS complexes that are present but occur independently of each other. This dissociation between atrial and ventricular activity is the hallmark of a third-degree AV block, also known as complete heart block.
