This scenario is a classic presentation of contraction alkalosis, a subtype of metabolic alkalosis caused by extracellular fluid loss. Incorrect Options: A: Respiratory Alkalosis This occurs due to hyperventilation, which leads to decreased CO? levels. Vomiting does not directly stimulate hyperventilation or cause a respiratory alkalosis, so this is not the expected acid-base disturbance here. B: Metabolic Acidosis Metabolic acidosis typically results from loss of bicarbonate (as in diarrhea) or accumulation of acids (e.g., DKA, lactic acidosis). Since vomiting leads to loss of acid, not base, acidosis is not expected in this case. D: Hyperkalemia Vomiting generally causes hypokalemia due to potassium loss from the GI tract and kidneys. Additionally, alkalosis promotes intracellular shifting of potassium, further lowering serum potassium levels. Therefore, hyperkalemia is not expected.

questions.text: CRITERIA FOR SEVERE COVID A/E
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) CT chest involvement CT chest involvement is not included in the formal criteria for defining severe COVID-19 as per WHO or NIH guidelines. While CT imaging can show lung involvement such as ground-glass opacities or consolidation, it is not a diagnostic or severity-defining criterion on its own. CT findings may support clinical assessment but are not part of the standardized criteria used to categorize disease severity. Thus, this is the exception among the listed options. Incorrect Options: A: SpO? < 90% An oxygen saturation below 90% on room air is a recognized marker of severe COVID-19, indicating significant hypoxia and impaired gas exchange, which is a critical clinical indicator for hospitalization and possibly oxygen therapy or ventilatory support. B: Respiratory rate > 30/min A respiratory rate over 30/min is a clinical marker of respiratory distress and is included in the definition of severe COVID-19. It reflects increased work of breathing and potential respiratory compromise, meeting severity criteria. C: Mean Arterial Pressure < 70 mmHg A MAP < 70 mmHg suggests hemodynamic instability or shock, which can occur in severe or critical COVID-19, especially when complicated by sepsis or multi-organ dysfunction. This makes it part of the criteria for critical illness or severe disease.

questions.text: PH : 7.28 Paco2 : 80 hco3 : 26 Diagnosis ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Respiratory acidosis with inadequate compensation The patient’s pH is 7.28, indicating acidemia. The PaCO? is 80 mmHg, which is markedly elevated (normal is ~40 mmHg), confirming a primary respiratory acidosis due to hypoventilation or CO? retention. The HCO?? is 26 mEq/L, which is only slightly elevated (normal: 22–26 mEq/L), suggesting the kidneys have not adequately compensated by retaining enough bicarbonate to buffer the increased CO?. In acute respiratory acidosis, for every 10 mmHg rise in PaCO?, HCO?? should increase by ~1 mEq/L (acute) or ~4 mEq/L (chronic). In this case, with a 40 mmHg rise in PaCO?, the expected compensation should be around +4 mEq/L (total HCO? ≈ 30 if chronic), but it's only 26 — confirming inadequate compensation, and most consistent with acute respiratory acidosis. Incorrect Options: A: Respiratory acidosis with adequate compensation As explained, the bicarbonate level (26) is not sufficiently elevated to compensate for the high PaCO? (80). So, this is not adequately compensated respiratory acidosis. C: Respiratory alkalosis with adequate compensation This is incorrect because the patient is acidotic (pH < 7.35), and the PaCO? is high, not low as would be expected in respiratory alkalosis. So, this is not alkalosis at all. D: Respiratory alkalosis with inadequate compensation Again, this option is ruled out because the disturbance is acidosis, not alkalosis. High PaCO? cannot be a feature of respiratory alkalosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is most specific antibody for SLE
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Anti-Smith (Anti-Sm) Anti-Smith (Anti-Sm) antibodies are the most specific antibody for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). While not the most sensitive (they are present in only ~30% of SLE cases), their presence is strongly associated with SLE and rarely found in other diseases, making them highly specific. This means that if a patient has anti-Sm antibodies, it is highly indicative of SLE, and they are even included in the classification criteria for SLE (ACR/EULAR) due to their diagnostic value. Therefore, Anti-Sm is the best marker when specificity is being asked. Incorrect options: A: ANA (Antinuclear Antibody) ANA is highly sensitive for SLE (~95–98%) but not specific, as it can be positive in a wide range of autoimmune diseases (e.g., systemic sclerosis, Sjögren's syndrome, even in healthy individuals especially the elderly). Thus, while it's a good screening test, it cannot confirm SLE specifically. B: Anti-dsDNA Anti-double stranded DNA (anti-dsDNA) is both sensitive and specific, but less specific than Anti-Sm. It is present in ~60–70% of SLE patients and is especially associated with renal involvement (lupus nephritis). However, it may rarely be seen in other conditions like chronic hepatitis or other autoimmune diseases. D: Anti-centromere Anti-centromere antibodies are not associated with SLE, but rather with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (CREST syndrome). Their presence would argue against SLE and point toward a scleroderma-spectrum disorder.

questions.text: What is the Amyloid deposition after Dialysis ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Beta-2 Microglobulin In patients undergoing long-term dialysis, the type of amyloid that gets deposited is primarily composed of Beta-2 microglobulin (β2M). This condition is called dialysis-related amyloidosis. β2-microglobulin is normally filtered by the kidneys, but in chronic kidney disease (CKD)—especially when patients are on hemodialysis for years—it accumulates in the blood due to poor clearance. Over time, this leads to amyloid fibril deposition, especially in joints, bones, and tendons (commonly causing carpal tunnel syndrome and arthropathy in dialysis patients). Therefore, Beta-2 microglobulin is the characteristic protein deposited in dialysis-related amyloidosis. Incorrect options: A: Light chains Light chains are deposited in AL amyloidosis, typically associated with plasma cell dyscrasias like multiple myeloma. They are not the type deposited in dialysis-related cases. B: Acute phase reactant Acute phase reactants, such as serum amyloid A (SAA), are involved in AA amyloidosis, seen in chronic inflammatory states like tuberculosis or rheumatoid arthritis—not in dialysis-related amyloidosis. C: Transthyretin (prealbumin) Transthyretin (TTR) is the amyloid protein in ATTR amyloidosis, which can be either hereditary or age-related (senile). It typically affects the heart and peripheral nerves, not associated with dialysis.

choices.text: Bicarbonaturia is a feature of RTA 2
RTA 4 is due to aldosterone resistance

questions.text: Choose incorrect statement about RTA
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) RTA 4 is associated with hypokalemia (Incorrect statement) This statement is incorrect, which is why it is the correct answer to this question. Renal Tubular Acidosis (RTA) type 4 is actually associated with hyperkalemia, not hypokalemia. It is typically seen in conditions of aldosterone deficiency or resistance, which leads to impaired potassium excretion by the distal nephron. As a result, potassium accumulates, causing hyperkalemia. This feature distinguishes RTA type 4 from other types of RTA, which more often present with hypokalemia. Correct statement B: Fanconi syndrome presents with RTA 2 This is a correct statement. Fanconi syndrome is a generalized dysfunction of the proximal tubule, leading to loss of glucose, amino acids, phosphate, and bicarbonate in urine. Loss of bicarbonate results in RTA type 2 (proximal RTA), making this statement accurate C: Bicarbonaturia is a feature of RTA 2 This is also a correct statement. In RTA type 2, there is impaired reabsorption of bicarbonate in the proximal tubule, leading to bicarbonaturia (loss of bicarbonate in the urine), especially in the early stages of the condition. This is a hallmark feature of proximal RTA. D: RTA 4 is due to aldosterone resistance This is another correct statement. RTA type 4 arises due to either aldosterone deficiency or aldosterone resistance, resulting in impaired sodium reabsorption and decreased potassium and proton excretion. This mechanism explains the hyperkalemia and mild metabolic acidosis seen in RTA 4.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is admitted to the medicine ward with complaints of vomiting and diarrhea. Lab investigations reveal a serum potassium level of 3.2 mEq/L. All of the following can be signs of underlying dyselectrolytemia except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Cerebral edema (Incorrect Statement) Cerebral edema is not typically associated with hypokalemia, and hence it is the correct answer to the question asking for an exception. Hypokalemia primarily affects muscle, cardiac, and renal systems, but it does not cause cerebral edema. Cerebral edema is more commonly linked with hyponatremia, where a low serum sodium concentration causes water to shift into brain cells, leading to swelling. In contrast, potassium disturbances do not cause significant osmotic shifts in the brain that would result in cerebral edema. Correct Statement A: Ventricular tachycardia Hypokalemia increases the risk of cardiac arrhythmias, especially ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation, due to increased myocardial excitability. ECG changes such as U waves, flattened T waves, and prolonged QT interval may be seen, all of which predispose to arrhythmias. B: Quadriplegia Severe hypokalemia can cause profound muscle weakness, which may progress to flaccid paralysis or quadriplegia in extreme cases. This occurs because potassium is critical for maintaining the resting membrane potential of muscle cells; a deficit impairs neuromuscular transmission. C: Diabetes insipidus Hypokalemia can cause a form of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. Low potassium impairs the renal tubule’s responsiveness to antidiuretic hormone (ADH), leading to polyuria and polydipsia, resembling diabetes insipidus. It is a recognized reversible cause of acquired nephrogenic DI.

choices.text: IV adenosine 6 mg bolus followed by saline push

questions.text: A man presents to the emergency department unconscious and hypotensive. His ECG reveals narrow complex tachycardia. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Synchronized DC cardioversion The best next step in the management of an unconscious and hypotensive patient with narrow complex tachycardia is synchronized direct current (DC) cardioversion. This is because the patient is unstable (evidenced by hypotension and altered sensorium), which is an immediate indication for electrical cardioversion, regardless of the ECG findings. In unstable patients, pharmacologic measures like adenosine or carotid massage are not safe or effective, and electrical cardioversion is both rapid and life-saving. Incorrect Options: B: Carotid massage Carotid sinus massage is a vagal maneuver used to terminate supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) in hemodynamically stable patients. However, this patient is unconscious and hypotensive, making vagal maneuvers inappropriate and potentially dangerous due to time delay and ineffectiveness in unstable patients. C: IV adenosine 6 mg bolus followed by saline push Adenosine is the first-line pharmacologic agent for stable narrow complex tachycardias, such as paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). However, in unstable patients like this one, electrical cardioversion is indicated over pharmacologic therapy to rapidly restore circulation. D: IV amiodarone bolus Amiodarone is used for rhythm control in atrial fibrillation, ventricular tachycardia, or when adenosine is contraindicated, but again, only in stable patients. In an emergency setting with hemodynamic instability, it is too slow-acting compared to DC cardioversion.

choices.text: ECG showing RA and RV collapse requires immediate intervention

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the emergency department with breathlessness. She has a history of a viral infection and chest pain from 7 days ago. A chest X-ray reveals a "water bottle" heart. All of the following statements are true except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Loud S1 Loud S1 is not a typical feature of a large pericardial effusion or cardiac tamponade, which is suggested in this case by the “water bottle” heart on chest X-ray. Instead, heart sounds—including S1—are usually muffled due to the insulating effect of fluid around the heart. The presence of breathlessness, history of recent viral illness, and chest pain, along with radiologic evidence, strongly points toward pericardial effusion, potentially progressing to cardiac tamponade. Thus, option B is the incorrect (false) statement, making it the right answer to the question. Incorrect Options: A: Pulsus paradoxus is observed This is true. Pulsus paradoxus—an exaggerated drop in systolic blood pressure (>10 mmHg) during inspiration—is a classic sign of cardiac tamponade. It reflects impaired ventricular filling due to increased pericardial pressure. C: Emergency pericardiocentesis may be required This is also true. If tamponade is present (e.g., causing hypotension or signs of shock), emergency pericardiocentesis is the definitive and often life-saving intervention to relieve pressure on the heart. D: ECG showing RA and RV collapse requires immediate intervention True. Echocardiographic evidence (not ECG) of right atrial and right ventricular diastolic collapse is a hallmark of tamponade physiology, which mandates urgent pericardiocentesis. While the question says "ECG", this likely refers to echo findings (a common confusion), and the interpretation focuses on the required immediate intervention, which is correct.

choices.text: Rare occurrence in individuals with normal heart
Direct Cardioversion must be done for all cases
Discrepancy in HR and PR used for diagnosis

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding a 35-yearold male presenting to the emergency department with unconsciousness and the given ECG findings?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Direct Cardioversion must be done for all cases (False Statement) This is the false statement, making it the correct choice for this question. Electrical (Direct) Cardioversion is not always required in all patients with AF. It is reserved for: Hemodynamically unstable patients (e.g., hypotension, shock, severe chest pain). Selected stable patients after evaluation (e.g., persistent AF with symptoms despite rate control). In many stable cases (especially if AF duration >48 hours), rate control with medications (like beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers, or digoxin) and anticoagulation are preferred initially. Hence, saying "must be done for all cases" is false. Other Options (True Statements): A. Rare occurrence in individuals with normal heart AF is rare in young individuals without structural heart disease. It usually occurs in the setting of hypertension, valvular disease, hyperthyroidism, etc. C. Intravenous digoxin for rate control Digoxin is a rate-controlling agent, especially useful in sedentary or elderly patients and those with heart failure. It’s used to slow AV nodal conduction in AF. D. Discrepancy in HR and PR used for diagnosis AF is diagnosed by irregularly irregular rhythm and absence of P waves. The pulse deficit (difference between apical and peripheral pulse rate) is due to variable ventricular filling — this is referred to as HR-PR discrepancy and supports AF diagnosis.

questions.text: Diabetic old man comes with dyspnea and pedal edema. CXR shows enlarged heart with rales. Echo shows low EF. Which of the following will delay the progression of cardiac damage?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Empagliflozin Empagliflozin, an SGLT2 inhibitor, has been shown to delay progression of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) and reduce cardiovascular mortality and hospitalizations, even in non-diabetic patients. In a diabetic patient with signs of congestive heart failure (dyspnea, pedal edema, enlarged heart, rales, low EF), empagliflozin provides both glycemic control and cardioprotective benefits. Its mechanisms include reducing preload and afterload, improving myocardial metabolism, and having diuretic-like effects without neurohormonal activation. It modifies disease progression, unlike other options that provide only symptomatic relief. Incorrect Options: A: Thiazides Thiazide diuretics are mainly antihypertensive agents and are not the first-line diuretics in heart failure. While they help in symptom relief of volume overload, they do not improve cardiac remodeling or delay progression of heart failure. C: Furosemide Furosemide is a loop diuretic, useful for rapid symptomatic relief of fluid overload (e.g., dyspnea and edema), but it does not modify the natural history of heart failure. It does not reduce mortality or slow progression of cardiac dysfunction. D: Digoxin Digoxin is used to improve symptoms and reduce hospitalizations in HFrEF, particularly when atrial fibrillation is present, but it does not delay cardiac damage or improve survival. It also has a narrow therapeutic index and potential toxicity, especially in elderly patients.

questions.text: Auscultation points. Superior to inferior on left side. 1. Pulmonic 2. Tricuspid 3. Mitral
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 1, 2, 3 On auscultation of the heart, we follow a superior to inferior anatomical approach on the left side of the chest, correlating with the valve areas: Pulmonic area – This is located at the 2nd left intercostal space, near the left upper sternal border. It is the most superior auscultation point on the left side. Tricuspid area – Located at the 4th or 5th left intercostal space, along the lower left sternal border. It lies below the pulmonic area. Mitral area – This is found at the 5th left intercostal space at the midclavicular line (the apex of the heart). It is inferior and lateral to both pulmonic and tricuspid areas. Hence, when moving superior to inferior, the order is: Pulmonic → Tricuspid → Mitral, or 1 → 2 → 3. Incorrect Options: A) 2, 1, 3: This incorrectly starts with the tricuspid (lower down) before the pulmonic (higher up). B) 1, 3, 2: This skips the correct order, placing mitral before tricuspid, which is anatomically higher on the sternum. D) 3, 2, 1: This is the reverse order from bottom to top, not superior to inferior as asked.

questions.text: A patient completes triple drug regimen for H pylori.Which investigation will be best to assess treatment response
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Breath urea test The urea breath test (UBT) is the most reliable and preferred non-invasive test to confirm eradication of H. pylori after treatment. It works by detecting urease activity, an enzyme produced by H. pylori that breaks down urea to release CO?, which is then measured in the patient’s breath. It is highly sensitive and specific and recommended 4 or more weeks after completion of therapy to avoid false negatives due to suppression of the bacteria by PPIs or antibiotics. Incorrect Options: A) Biopsy urease test This is an invasive test requiring endoscopy. It is less commonly used post-treatment unless endoscopy is already indicated for other reasons. Additionally, false negatives can occur due to patchy infection or recent antibiotics/PPI use. B) Upper GI endoscopy While it provides direct visualization, it is not necessary for routine assessment of H. pylori eradication unless there are alarm symptoms or non-healing ulcers. It's invasive and not cost-effective for routine follow-up. D) Serology Serological tests detect antibodies, which can remain positive for months to years after successful treatment. Hence, they do not differentiate between active and past infection and are not useful for assessing treatment success.

questions.text: A 52 year old patient with diabetes presented with palpitations. On examination BP- 128/78 mmHg. ECG done is shown in the figure. What will be the next step in the management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Adenosine ECG Interpretation & Clinical Context: This is an ECG showing a narrow complex tachycardia with: Regular rhythm Rate >150 bpm P waves not clearly visible or may be seen retrogradely or buried in QRS These findings are classic for Paroxysmal Supraventricular Tachycardia (PSVT), most likely AVNRT (Atrioventricular Nodal Reentrant Tachycardia). The patient is hemodynamically stable (BP 128/78 mmHg), so pharmacologic therapy is preferred. Adenosine is the first-line treatment for stable narrow complex tachycardia due to AV nodal reentrant mechanisms. It works by transiently blocking AV node conduction, which may terminate AVNRT or unmask atrial activity if the rhythm is not AV node–dependent. Incorrect Options: A) Primary PCI Indicated in ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI), not for PSVT. No ST elevation is seen here. C) Cardioversion Used in unstable tachycardias (e.g., hypotension, altered mental status, shock, ischemia). This patient is stable, so drug therapy is preferred. D) Amiodarone Reserved for broad complex tachycardias or when adenosine and beta blockers fail. Not first-line in narrow complex tachycardia.

choices.text: The effect is due to rapid correction of Na
The effect is due to slow correction of Na

questions.text: A patient has vomiting and no proper dietary intake for 4 weeks. He was treated aggressively with IV NS following which the patient developed quadriplegia and became rigid and mute. Correct statement
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The effect is due to rapid correction of Na The scenario describes a classic case of osmotic demyelination syndrome (ODS), previously known as central pontine myelinolysis.The patient had vomiting and poor dietary intake for 4 weeks, which likely led to chronic hyponatremia.He was then treated aggressively with IV normal saline, which can rapidly raise serum sodium levels.Rapid correction of chronic hyponatremia is a well-known cause of ODS, which presents with quadriplegia, mutism, rigidity, pseudobulbar palsy, or locked-in syndrome.Chronic hyponatremia leads to brain adaptation by reducing intracellular osmolytes. Rapid Na+ correction reverses this osmotic gradient too quickly, causing neuronal dehydration and demyelination, especially in the pons. Incorrect Options: B) The effect is due to slow correction of Na Slow correction of sodium is the recommended approach in chronic hyponatremia. It prevents ODS, not causes it. C) Dehydration While dehydration may have contributed to the initial hyponatremia or clinical presentation, it does not directly cause quadriplegia and mutism after saline therapy. D) Metabolic acidosis There is no mention of acid-base disturbance here, and metabolic acidosis does not typically lead to this specific neurological presentation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the outpatient department with proximal muscle weakness, purple stretch marks, obesity, and easy bruising. What is the underlying condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hypercortisolism The clinical presentation of proximal muscle weakness, purple striae (stretch marks), central obesity, and easy bruising is classic for Cushing's syndrome, which is caused by hypercortisolism—an excess of cortisol in the body. Key features explained Proximal muscle weakness: Cortisol causes protein catabolism, leading to muscle wasting. Purple striae: Stretch marks on the abdomen or thighs that are wide and violaceous, due to collagen breakdown and skin thinning. Central obesity: Cortisol redistributes fat to the trunk, face ("moon face"), and dorsocervical fat pad ("buffalo hump"). Easy bruising: Cortisol impairs collagen formation and capillary integrity. These signs strongly point toward Cushing's syndrome, either due to exogenous steroid use or endogenous cortisol overproduction (like adrenal adenoma or pituitary adenoma producing ACTH). Incorrect Options: A) Hyperthyroidism Typically presents with weight loss, heat intolerance, tremors, palpitations, and hyperactivity. Muscle weakness may occur but without purple striae or central obesity. C) Hyperparathyroidism Causes hypercalcemia, which may result in bone pain, kidney stones, abdominal groans, and psychiatric moans, not the features mentioned here. D) Hyperaldosteronism Leads to hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis. It does not cause skin changes, bruising, or fat redistribution.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with symptoms of headache, abdominal pain and recently developed renal stone. Serum calcium is low and PTH is high. Which of the following might be causing these symptoms?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Mineral and Bone Disorder The patient's presentation includes: Headache, abdominal pain Renal stone Low serum calcium Elevated PTH (parathyroid hormone) This constellation suggests a secondary hyperparathyroidism scenario, often seen in chronic kidney disease (CKD) leading to Mineral and Bone Disorder (MBD). In CKD, phosphate retention and decreased vitamin D activation reduce calcium levels, stimulating a compensatory rise in PTH (i.e., secondary hyperparathyroidism). Over time, this dysregulation causes renal osteodystrophy and may lead to soft tissue and vascular calcifications, nephrolithiasis (stones), and bone pain. So, this patient likely has a CKD-related Mineral and Bone Disorder, where low calcium with high PTH is a hallmark finding. Incorrect Options: A) PTH and Primary Hyperparathyroidism In primary hyperparathyroidism, serum calcium is high and PTH is inappropriately elevated. However, the question states low calcium, making this option incorrect. B) Catecholamines and Pheochromocytoma Pheochromocytoma typically presents with episodic hypertension, sweating, palpitations, and headaches, but not with low calcium or elevated PTH. C) Thyroxine and Hyperthyroidism Hyperthyroidism can cause bone resorption leading to mild hypercalcemia, not low calcium. It does not typically raise PTH levels.

questions.text: All of the following are criteria for diagnosis of diabetes ketoacidosis, except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Serum potassium less than 3.5 mEq/L Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA) is diagnosed based on clinical and biochemical criteria. While potassium abnormalities are common in DKA, a serum potassium < 3.5 mEq/L is not a diagnostic criterion. In fact, at presentation, most DKA patients have normal or elevated serum potassium despite total body potassium depletion due to extracellular shift caused by acidosis and insulin deficiency. Importantly, DKA is not diagnosed by low potassium, though it must be closely monitored and corrected during treatment. Starting insulin therapy in a patient with hypokalemia (<3.3 mEq/L) is dangerous and should be avoided until potassium is corrected. Incorrect Options: A) Serum glucose more than 250 mg/dL Correct diagnostic criterion for DKA. Hyperglycemia is typically marked and a key component. B) Anion gap more than 10–12 DKA is a high anion gap metabolic acidosis, so an elevated anion gap is a defining criterion. C) Serum bicarbonate less than 15 mmol/L Low bicarbonate reflects the severity of metabolic acidosis and is a diagnostic criterion for DKA (usually <18 mmol/L; <15 indicates moderate to severe DKA).

questions.text: 55 year old male presented with Weakness in the left side of the body.. he patient was asked to redraw that and he was only able to draw the right half of the handwritten image. Held draw from clock hours 6-12. It was suggestive of Left Hemianopia what could be the possible site of lesion?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Right Parieto-Occipital Cortex The patient has left hemianopia (loss of vision in the left half of the visual field in both eyes), which indicates damage posterior to the optic chiasm, affecting the right visual pathway. Additionally, the clock drawing test showing neglect of the left side suggests left hemispatial neglect, which is commonly associated with right parietal lobe lesions. The right parieto-occipital cortex is involved in visual processing and spatial attention. A lesion here can produce: Left homonymous hemianopia (due to occipital lobe involvement) Left hemispatial neglect (due to parietal lobe involvement) Thus, the combination of left hemianopia and visual neglect points strongly to a right parieto-occipital lesion. Incorrect Options: B) Right Frontal Cortex Lesions here may cause motor weakness (e.g., left-sided due to contralateral control) but do not cause hemianopia or visual neglect typically. C) Left Parieto-Occipital Cortex Would cause right hemianopia, not left. Also, left hemisphere lesions usually do not cause hemispatial neglect, as this function is typically dominant in the right hemisphere. D) Left Frontal Cortex Would be associated with right-sided motor symptoms, possible expressive aphasia (if dominant side), but not left hemianopia or neglect. .

questions.text: Which of the following is not a reversible cause of dementia
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Lewy Body Dementia Lewy Body Dementia (LBD) is not reversible. It is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder, characterized by abnormal deposits of alpha-synuclein (Lewy bodies) in the brain. LBD shares features with both Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's disease, including: Fluctuating cognition Visual hallucinations Parkinsonism REM sleep behavior disorder There is no cure, and management is primarily supportive and symptomatic. Hence, it is not considered a reversible cause of dementia. Incorrect Options (All are Reversible Causes of Dementia): A) Hypothyroidism Yes, reversible. Hypothyroidism can lead to cognitive slowing and memory issues that resemble dementia (sometimes called "pseudodementia"). Treatment with thyroid hormone replacement often resolves cognitive symptoms. C) Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH) Yes, potentially reversible. NPH presents with the classic triad: Gait disturbance Urinary incontinence Dementia If diagnosed early, ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunting can significantly improve or reverse symptoms. D) Vitamin B12 Deficiency Yes, reversible. B12 deficiency can cause subacute combined degeneration and cognitive impairment. Timely vitamin B12 replacement can restore normal cognitive function, especially if treated early.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with weakness in both legs, increased muscle tone, brisk reflexes, and a well-defined band of sensory loss at the level of the umbilicus. He also reports difficulty in passing urine. Which of the following best explains the likely site of lesion
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Thoracic spinal cord lesion The patient presents with bilateral lower limb weakness, increased tone, brisk reflexes, a sensory level at the umbilicus, and urinary retention. These findings are classic for a spinal cord lesion, particularly at the thoracic level: Sensory level at the umbilicus corresponds to T10 dermatome, indicating that the lesion is likely in the thoracic spinal cord. Bilateral weakness with increased tone and brisk reflexes are signs of upper motor neuron (UMN) involvement. Urinary retention suggests involvement of descending autonomic pathways controlling bladder function, commonly affected in spinal cord lesions. Thus, a thoracic spinal cord lesion is the most consistent with the described presentation. Incorrect Options: A) Peripheral neuropathy Peripheral neuropathy typically causes lower motor neuron signs such as flaccid weakness, reduced tone, diminished reflexes, and glove-and-stocking sensory loss. It does not cause a sensory level or spasticity. B) Cerebral cortex lesion Cortical lesions may cause contralateral weakness, typically more unilateral and not associated with a sensory level. They also wouldn't selectively affect bladder or bowel function unless bilateral or involving the paracentral lobule. D) Brainstem lesion Brainstem lesions usually affect cranial nerves, respiratory centers, or cause mixed cranial and long tract signs. They rarely present with an isolated thoracic sensory level or bilateral lower limb findings alone.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with sudden onset of violent, flinging movements of his left arm and leg. MRI shows a small infarct in the basal ganglia. Which of the following structures is most likely affected?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Right Subthalamic nucleus The patient's presentation — sudden onset of violent, flinging movements (termed hemiballismus) — is a classic manifestation of a lesion in the subthalamic nucleus. The subthalamic nucleus is part of the basal ganglia indirect pathway, which normally inhibits movement. A lesion in the subthalamic nucleus results in loss of inhibition, leading to excessive, involuntary, flinging limb movements (ballismus). Because of crossed motor control, left-sided symptoms suggest a lesion in the right subthalamic nucleus. Incorrect Options: B) Right Caudate nucleus Lesions here are more commonly associated with chorea (as seen in Huntington's disease), which is characterized by brief, irregular, dance-like movements, not the violent, large-amplitude flinging of hemiballismus. C) Left Globus pallidus Involvement of the globus pallidus may lead to rigidity or dystonia, not typically hemiballismus. Also, a left-sided lesion would not match left-sided symptoms due to contralateral control. D) Left Putamen Like the globus pallidus, the putamen is involved in movement regulation, but putaminal lesions more often produce parkinsonism or chorea, not hemiballismus. Again, a left-sided lesion would more likely affect the right side of the body.

questions.text: A patient on ventilator presents with cough and breathlessness. VAP is diagnosed. What is the role of procalcitonin?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Deciding the duration of antibiotics •Procalcitonin is a biomarker elevated in bacterial infections and is used to guide antibiotic stewardship. •It does not confirm VAP but helps in deciding when to stop antibiotics, thereby reducing overuse. •It doesn’t help in choosing empirical therapy, nor in differentiating fungal from bacterial causes reliably.
